main event: On 19 February 1958, a ground-radar observation in Hokkaido, Japan, reported rapidly moving objects that expanded to cover approximately 15 miles, resembling the explosion of a large munitions ship. This observation lasted for 2 hours.
interesting points: The radar showed rapidly moving objects resembling weather conditions, but it expanded to cover a large area.
There was an association with the explosion of a large munitions ship, although the exact cause was unidentified.
The observation lasted for an extended period of 2 hours, allowing for a detailed analysis of the event.
A connection to Russian aircraft tracks in the area was reported, adding further complexity to the sighting.
Witnesses observed and tracked three luminous objects over a two-month period along the Hokkaido Coast, with the cases being classified as unexplained and forwarded for further information.
sighted object: rapidly moving objects resembling an explosion
witnesses: Military personnel and safety board officials
